conclusion: Analyze the path of light rays through the semicircular glass brick to determine the width of the portion of the base through which light passes.
Light rays strike the flat base of the glass brick at an angle \(\pi - \gamma\) relative to the horizontal plane of the base.
Determine the refraction angle using Snell's Law: \(n_1 \sin(\theta_1) = n_2 \sin(\theta_2)\).
Critical angle \(\gamma\) is given, and total internal reflection occurs if the angle of incidence inside the glass is greater than or equal to \(\gamma\).
Light rays travel through the semicircular surface and refract again when exiting the glass. The angle of incidence at the curved surface is \(\gamma\).
Calculate the width of light passing through the base, where rays tangent to the curved surface define the boundary of this width.
Tangent rays form a right triangle with the radius \(R\) of the semicircle, and the angle between the tangent ray and the radius is \(\gamma\).
Determine the width \(W\) using trigonometric relationships: \(W = 2R \cos(\gamma)\).
The width of the portion of the base through which light passes is \(2R \cos(\gamma)\).
